text.front:
International Journal of Modern Physics D
Vol. 24, No. 1 (2015) 1550007 (14 pages)
c
World Scientific Publishing Company
DOI: 10.1142/S0218271815500078
Kerr–Newman solution in modified teleparallel
theory of gravity
Gamal G. L. Nashed *
Centre for Theoretical Physics,
The British University in Egypt,
Sherouk City 11837, P.O. Box 43, Egypt
nashed@bue.edu.eg
Received 11 July 2014
Revised 27 September 2014
Accepted 28 October 2014
Published 27 November 2014
A nondiagonal tetrad field having six unknown functions plus an angle Φ, which is a
function of the radial coordinate r, azimuthal angle θ and the polar angle φ, is applied
to the charged field equations of modified teleparallel theory of gravity. A special non-
vacuum solution is derived with three constants of integration. The tetrad field of this
solution is axially symmetric and its scalar torsion is constant. The associated metric
of the derived solution gives Kerr–Newman spacetime. We have shown that the derived
solution can be described by a local Lorentz transformations plus a diagonal tetrad field
that is the square root of the Kerr–Newman metric. We show that any solution of general
relativity (GR) can be a solution in f (T ) under certain conditions.
Keywords: f (T ) Theories of gravity; charged axially symmetric solution; energy.
PACS Number(s): 04.50.Kd, 04.70.Bw, 04.20.Jb
text.body:
1. Introduction
Cosmological observations containing the cosmic microwave background,
1,2 the
Hubble parameter,
3 type Ia supernovae
4 and baryon acoustic oscillations surveys,
5
suggest that our Universe is currently undergoing a phase of accelerated expansion.
The proposals that have been put to explain such discoveries can be classified into
two categories: One is to assume the cosmic speed-up might be caused within gen-
eral relativity (GR) by a cosmic fluid with negative pressure, which is called dark
energy (DE). However, the nature of DE is still unknown and is still one of the
hardest and unresolved problems in modern theoretical physics.
6,7
text.front:
* Address: Mathematics Department, Faculty of Science, Ain Shams University, Cairo, 11566,
Egypt.

2nd Reading
November 25, 2014 12:56 WSPC/S0218-2718
142-IJMPD
1550007
G. G. L. Nashed
text.body:
A possible equivalence between the equations of GR can be obtain consider-
ing a spacetime where the curvature contributions vanish and the unique non-null
contribution is coming from the antisymmetric part of the connection. This scenario
is called Weitzenbök spacetime. Through this equivalence, one analyzes the physical
phenomena of the gravitation and the cosmology, which until now are not clearly
known using the GR. Hence, we can try to understand the contribution of the
terms of higher-order in curvature, added to the Einstein–Hilbert term as can be
observed in the common theories, f (R),
8 f (G),
9 f (R, T )
10 and f (R, G).
11 In the
case of the theory equivalent to the GR, the Teleparallel Equivalent of General
Relativity (TEGR),
12 the attention is attached to the torsion scalar T which plays
an important role in constructing the action of the theory. Hence, as in the case of
GR, a generalization of the TEGR must contain terms of higher-order in T that we
call f (T ) gravitational theory,
13 where f (T ) is an algebraic function of the torsion
scalar T .
Recently, special attention has been attached to the f (T ) gravity. Møller and
other authors undertook and developed the proposal for an analogy between the
teleparallel gravity and the GR.
14 Models based on f (T ) gravity were investigated,
on one hand as an alternative to inflationary models
15,16 and on the other hand, as
an alternative to dark energy models.
17 Recently, still in the framework of f (T )
gravity, new spherically symmetric solutions of black holes and wormholes are
obtained in Refs. 13–22. Power-law solutions of the scale factor are investigated
when the Universe enters a phantom phase and it is shown that such power-law
solutions may exist as cosmological model in the framework of f (T ) gravity.
The f (T ) gravity appears in cosmology as the source driving the inflation.
15
Also, it has been used as a theory that reproduces the acceleration of the Uni-
verse without the necessity of introducing dark energy.
23 The contributions of the
cosmological perturbations of this theory have been studied.
24 In gravitation, the
first model of black hole which has been analyzed was the BTZ.
16 Recently, in the
framework of f (T ) gravity, several black holes and wormhole solutions with spher-
ical symmetry have been found in Refs. 25–40. Moreover, other analysis about
various themes are being investigated in the context of f (T ) gravity.
41 Izumi et al.
have shown the existence of physical superluminal modes and a causality in the
Brans–Dicke type of extension of teleparallel gravity that includes f (T ) gravity
and teleparallel dark energy as special cases.
42 Several examples from gauge field
theories to explain how such superluminal modes could arise have been provided.
43
It is the aim of the present work, within the framework of extended theory of
teleparallel gravity, f (T ), to find a charged axially symmetric solution. In Sec. 2,
a brief review of f (T ) theory is given. In Sec. 3, a tetrad field with six unknown
functions of the radial coordinate, r, and an azimuth angle θ is applied to the field
equation of TEGR, f (T ) = T . A solution to the field equation of TEGR is given
in Sec. 3. This solution is substituting into the tetrad and we generalize the angle
φ by an angle Φ which is a function of the radial coordinate r, azimuthal angle
θ and the polar angle φ, i.e. Φ = L(r, θ, φ) is provided. Application of the field

text.body:
equation of f (T ) to this tetrad, the one with generalized angle Φ, is given in Sec. 3.
A new nonvacuum, axially symmetric solution with three constants of integration
is derived in Sec. 3. In Sec. 4, we rewrite the derived solution as a local Lorentz
transformation, which depends on the generalized angle Φ, and a diagonal tetrad
of the Kerr–Newman spacetime. The final section is a summary of the results.

Now we are going to rewrite Eq. (7) in another form: The field equation (7) is
written in terms of the tetrad and its partial derivatives. This equation appears to
be different from Einstein's field equations. Following,
32 one can obtain an equation
relating T with the Ricci scalar of the metric, R. These will make the equivalence
between teleparallel gravity and GR clear. On the other hand, the tetrad cannot
be eliminated completely in favor of the metric in Eq. (7), because of the lack
of local Lorentz symmetry. However, we will show that the latter can be brought
in a form that closely resembles Einstein's equation. This form is more suitable
for constructing analytic solutions in the f (T ) theory. To start writing the field
equations in a covariant version, we must replace partial derivatives in the tensors
by covariant derivatives compatible with the metric g µν , i.e. ∇ σ where ∇ σ g µν = 0.
Thus, Eq. (3) can be written as

(15)
Equation (15) can be taken as the starting point of the f (T ) modified gravity
model, and it has a structure similar to the field equation of f (R) gravity. Note
that in the more general case with f (T ) = T the field equations are covariant form.
Nevertheless, the theory is not local Lorentz invariant. In case of f (T ) = T and
constant torsion, f (T 0 ), GR is recovered and field equations are covariant and the
theory is Lorentz invariant.
3. Axially Symmetric Solution in f (T ) Gravity Theory

Equation (24) shows that the energy-momentum tensor depends on the constant
c 2 , i.e. charge parameter q and when it is vanishing the components of the energy-
momentum-tensor are also vanishing.
Solution (21) is a solution to TEGR, i.e. f (T ) = T but not for f (T ) theory.
Therefore, to find an analytic solution within f (T ) gravitational theories we need
to parameterize the angle φ, i.e. makes the angle φ function of the radial coordinate
r, azimuthal angle θ and the polar angle φ, L(r, θ, φ). Then we calculate the tor-
sion scalar which will be a partial differential equation of one unknown L(r, θ, φ).
From this differential equation, we can put a constraint on the scalar torsion to be
constant. Let us explain this procedure in detail: By substituting solution (21) in
the tetrad field (16) we get

Equation (31) is a local Lorentz transformation.
Equation (32) has the same metric of tetrad field (25). We call Eq. (32) the
diagonal form of tetrad field (25).
5. Main Results and Discussion
Modifications of gravitational theories succeeded partially in solving some recent
observational problems. Among these modifications is the f (T ) gravitational the-
ories. In the framework of such modification, it is not an easy task to derive ana-
lytical solutions. In this paper, we have studied the nonvacuum case of f (T ), i.e.
T
emν
mu = 0. The field equations in the case f (T ) = T , have been applied to a
nondiagonal, axially symmetric, tetrad field having six unknown functions of radial
coordinate, r and azimuthal coordinate θ. The resulting nonlinear partial differential
equations are solved and we have derived an analytical solution whose associated
metric gave Kerr–Newman spacetime. This solution is not a solution to the f (T )
field equations. Therefore, we have substituted the derived solution in the tetrad
field and rewrite this tetrad in terms of an angle Φ which is a function of the radial
coordinate r, azimuthal angle θ and the polar angle φ i.e., Φ = L(r, θ, φ). We have
applied this tetrad field, the one with the generalized angle φ, to the field equa-
tions of f (T ) and have calculated its scalar torsion T and its derivatives. To find a
solution to the field equations of f (T ) gravitational theory we have put the scalar
torsion equal constant, T = T 0 and have solved the differential equation. We have
obtained a value of L(r, θ, φ) which makes the torsion scalar equal constant. This
condition, T = T 0 , makes the term which contains f T T of the field equation of f (T )
to be vanishing and therefore, we obtained a solution to the field equations of f (T )
provided that Eq. (29) is satisfied. In addition, this solution has axial symmetry,
i.e. the components of its tetrad field are invariant under the change of the angle Φ.
The associated metric of the solutions of f (T ) = T or of f (T ) gave Kerr–Newman
spacetime.
To shed light on the internal construction of the derived solution we have written
it as a local Lorentz transformation and a diagonal tetrad
d . The local Lorentz
transformation is related to so(3). This local Lorentz transformation depends on
the generalized angle Φ, rotation and charge parameters and it reduces to the one
studied in Refs. 19, 21 and 22 when these parameters vanished and Φ = φ.
The way of writing tetrad field (25) as a local Lorentz transformation and diag-
onal one as given by Eqs. (31) and (32) is not unique. For example: If the form of
tetrad field (32) is changed then the form of (31) changes.
text.note: d Diagonal means the square root of the metric.

Equation (35) is local Lorentz transformations.
To sum up, solution (28) justifies that any GR solution remains valid in f (T )
theories having f T (const.) = 1 whenever the geometry admits a tetrad field with
constant scalar torsion, T .
